channel.copyright: Copyright 2015 The New York Times Company

item.title: White House Antagonism Toward Netanyahu Grows
item.description: Despite Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s election victory, he is still out of the good graces of the Obama administration, which has had to reassess its policy toward Israel.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS

item.title: World Briefing: Liberia Reports First Ebola Case in Weeks
item.description: Confirmation that a patient tested positive deflated hope that Liberia was now free of the Ebola virus.
item.dc:creator: SHERI FINK and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: The Saturday Profile: A French Politician Who Has Helped Refine the National Front Party
item.description: Experts say Florian Philippot has been critical in the party’s efforts to present a respectable face — and one that is ready to govern.
item.dc:creator: SUZANNE DALEY
item.media:description: Florian Philippot, 33, is the National Front’s vice president in charge of communications and strategy.

item.title: Abiding Rifts Within Israel Threaten to Widen With Netanyahu Win
item.description: After Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu’s victory, Israelis began to confront the social and political fissures that crisscross the country.
item.dc:creator: ISABEL KERSHNER

item.title: Latest Iran Talks End Without a Deal
item.description: No initial agreement was reached on limiting Iran’s nuclear program, but the negotiations will resume next week in Switzerland.
item.dc:creator: MICHAEL R. GORDON
item.media:description: The Iranian delegation in Lausanne, Switzerland, on Friday before the latest talks on Iran's nuclear program.

item.title: Afghan Leader Said to Be Centralizing Power as Unity Government Plan Stalls
item.description: Although President Ashraf Ghani’s aides deny the accusations, there is growing concern that cooperating with his rival, Abdullah Abdullah, is not high on his list.
item.dc:creator: AZAM AHMED
item.media:description: From left, Hamid Karzai, the former president of Afghanistan; Ashraf Ghani, the current president; and Abdullah Abdullah, the Afghan government's chief executive officer, in Kabul on March 9.

item.title: European Leaders Urge Greece to Accelerate Overhaul Efforts
item.description: After late-night talks, French, German and Greek leaders asserted that Greece could get back on track by speeding up the implementation of a February agreement.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS and JAMES KANTER

item.title: Op-Ed Contributor: Finding This Lost City in Honduras Was the Easy Part
item.description: Deciding what to do with the ancient artifacts there was harder.
item.dc:creator: TOM LUTZ

item.title: 5 Babies Found Dead in French Village
item.description: The bodes, four of them hidden in a freezer, were found in a home in Louchats, a rural village in southern France.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Q. and A.: Chang-rae Lee on His Tale of Migrants From an Environmentally Ruined China
item.description: The Korean-American author’s new novel, “On Such a Full Sea,” centers on a Chinese woman named Fan who is a laborer in a city called B-Mor, a future version of Baltimore.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Europeans (Carefully) Gaze Upward for Glimpse of the Solar Eclipse
item.description: As officials warned of possible power failures and encouraged people to view the phenomenon only through special glasses, excitement grew for the rare celestial event.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY and MELISSA EDDY

item.title: Suicide Attacks at Mosques in Yemen Kill More Than 130
item.description: A previously unknown Yemeni affiliate of the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the attacks at two Zaydi Shiite mosques in Sana, the capital.
item.dc:creator: MOHAMMED ALI KALFOOD and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:description: Victims of mosque bombings in the Yemeni capital were evacuated on Friday. There was no immediate claim of responsibility.

item.title: Malcolm Fraser, a Leader Given Power During Crisis in Australia, Dies at 84
item.description: Mr. Fraser became prime minister of Australia during a constitutional crisis but later won three elections and led his country for eight years.
item.dc:creator: LIAM STACK

item.title: At Least 32 Killed After Express Train Strikes Barrier in Northern India
item.description: Dozens of people were reported injured after two coaches and the engine derailed in Uttar Pradesh, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: NIDA NAJAR

item.title: Militants Attack Police Station in India
item.description: The heavily armed militants, wearing Indian Army uniforms, opened fire on a station near the Pakistani border, leaving six people dead
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: Sinosphere Blog: Hackers Attack GreatFire.org, a Workaround for Websites Censored in China
item.description: Unidentified hackers have attacked GreatFire.org, a website that provides access to news websites blocked by China.
item.dc:creator: PATRICK BOEHLER
item.media:description: Computer users in an Internet cafe in Beijing.

item.title: Nigerian Army Noticeably Absent in Town Taken From Boko Haram
item.description: Soldiers from Chad and Niger had succeeded in chasing Boko Haram out of Damasak, Nigeria, but there was not a single Nigerian soldier to be found.
item.dc:creator: ADAM NOSSITER
item.media:description: Chadian soldiers in Damasak on Wednesday, only days after the town was liberated from Boko Haram militants.

item.title: Brazil’s Slumping Economy and Bribery Scandal Eat Away at Dilma Rousseff’s Popularity
item.description: President Rousseff is fighting for her political survival, as her approval rating falls and the national oil company she once oversaw reels from a corruption scandal.
item.dc:creator: SIMON ROMERO

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Case for Free-Range Parenting
item.description: Why are Americans so afraid to give their kids room to roam?
item.dc:creator: CLEMENS WERGIN

item.title: Open Source: Greco-German ‘Fingergate’ Gets Curiouser and Curiouser
item.description: The debate over an obscene gesture by Greece’s finance minister took a comic turn as a German satirist claimed to have faked video of it.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: Jan Böhmermann, a German satirist, suggested that his nation's response to the Greek finance minister's gesture was slightly over the top.
